title: How to Make a Healthy Spinach and Garlic Dish

steps.headline: Purchase a package of fresh spinach from your grocer.
steps.description: It can be either the "old school" bundled variety (with dirt still on the leaves/stems) or the cleaned, packaged variety.

steps.headline: Cut about an inch off the bottom of the stems (if using the bundled type)
Fill your sink with clean, cold water and add the spinach.
steps.description: Move around to clean and let soak for some minutes to let any dirt settle to bottom of sink. While soaking, prepare next steps

steps.headline: Take a couple of cloves of garlic and slightly smash with the flat side of a knife to remove skin.
Place a 6-8 quart pot (reserve lid for use later on) on the stove; add 3-4 tablespoons of olive oil.
steps.description: Extra Virgin produces a nice flavor.

steps.headline: Add the garlic cloves to the pot and slowly heat the oil over medium/low heat.
Cook the garlic cloves until they are golden on each side.
steps.description: It is imperative not to brown them too much, or turn them black, as this will result in an unpleasant flavor.

steps.headline: While the garlic is cooking, take the spinach out of the water and place in a colander.
steps.description: Do not shake the spinach dry; the water on the spinach is an important part of the process.

steps.headline: As soon as the garlic has become golden brown, add the spinach to the pot.
steps.description: A great deal of sizzling/noise will occur as the wet spinach hits the hot oil This is normal and good.

steps.headline: Immediately place the lid on the pot and let the spinach cook down for about 3 minutes.
steps.description: Open the lid, add some salt, pepper and, if you like it, a pinch of crushed red pepper. Give the spinach a stir, cover the pot and turn the stove off.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The spinach is now ready for eating with crusty or toasted bread.

Cut about an inch off the bottom of the stems (if using the bundled type)  Fill your sink with clean, cold water and add the spinach. Move around to clean and let soak for some minutes to let any dirt settle to bottom of sink. While soaking, prepare next steps Take a couple of cloves of garlic and slightly smash with the flat side of a knife to remove skin.  Place a 6-8 quart pot (reserve lid for use later on) on the stove; add 3-4 tablespoons of olive oil. Extra Virgin produces a nice flavor. Add the garlic cloves to the pot and slowly heat the oil over medium/low heat.  Cook the garlic cloves until they are golden on each side. It is imperative not to brown them too much, or turn them black, as this will result in an unpleasant flavor. While the garlic is cooking, take the spinach out of the water and place in a colander. Do not shake the spinach dry; the water on the spinach is an important part of the process. As soon as the garlic has become golden brown, add the spinach to the pot. A great deal of sizzling/noise will occur as the wet spinach hits the hot oil This is normal and good. Immediately place the lid on the pot and let the spinach cook down for about 3 minutes. Open the lid, add some salt, pepper and, if you like it, a pinch of crushed red pepper. Give the spinach a stir, cover the pot and turn the stove off. Serve. The spinach is now ready for eating with crusty or toasted bread.
